disposable_income: Rogers Park has a median household income of around $47,000, lower than Chicago's median. About 27% of residents live below poverty level. Many residents are cost-sensitive and need to carefully manage transportation expenses.
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Many residents are students or working-class families who need to balance basic needs with transportation costs. Higher sales taxes would notably impact household budgets.
accessibility: High transit accessibility with Red Line L station and multiple bus routes. About 35% of households don't own cars. Many residents rely on public transit for commuting to work/school. Walking and biking are common due to dense, walkable neighborhood layout.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares due to high transit dependency and lower incomes. 2. Moderate sales tax to maintain service quality while not overly burdening limited discretionary spending. 3. Support some driving fees to improve transit service and reduce congestion, but not highest level due to needed car access for some residents. 4. Balance between transit time improvements and cost burden. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable.

disposable_income: West Ridge has a mixed-income population with median household income around $54,000. About 18% of residents live below poverty level. Many residents are price-sensitive to transportation costs.
discretionary_consumption: Moderate levels of discretionary spending. The community has significant immigrant populations who tend to be cost-conscious. Many households need to carefully budget transportation expenses.
accessibility: Good bus service along major arterials but limited rail access. About 30% of households don't own cars and rely on transit. Many residents commute to jobs downtown and other parts of the city. Walking access to local shopping districts on Devon and Western.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares ($0.75) to help transit-dependent residents while maintaining service quality. 2. Moderate tax rate (1%) balances revenue needs with household budgets. 3. Support modest driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to reduce congestion and fund transit without overly burdening drivers. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times to help commuters. 5. Consider proposals that maintain reasonable driving costs for car-dependent households while encouraging transit use.

disposable_income: Uptown has a mixed-income population with median household income around $53,000. About 23% of residents live below poverty level. Many residents are cost-sensitive and rely on public transportation.
discretionary_consumption: Given the income levels, many residents have limited discretionary spending. Higher sales taxes would impact household budgets significantly. The area has many renters and working-class families who need to carefully manage transportation costs.
accessibility: Uptown has excellent transit access with Red Line L, multiple bus routes, and is relatively walkable. About 35% of households don't own cars. The area has high transit usage for commuting. Many residents rely on transit to access jobs downtown and other areas.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares and moderate taxes given income constraints and high transit reliance. 2. Support some driving fees to improve transit service and reduce congestion. 3. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden. 4. Consider proposals that reduce transit travel times. 5. Favor options that maintain transit affordability while generating revenue for service improvements. Selected proposals optimize these factors while keeping costs manageable for lower-income residents.

disposable_income: Lincoln Square is a middle to upper-middle income area with median household income around $77,000. Residents have moderate disposable income but are price-sensitive to transportation costs.
discretionary_consumption: The area has significant retail and entertainment spending, with many local businesses, restaurants and shops. Residents generally have good discretionary spending power but are value-conscious.
accessibility: Well-served by CTA Brown Line and multiple bus routes. Good walkability and bikeability. Many residents commute downtown for work. Mix of transit users and drivers, with about 35% using public transit for commuting.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize balanced policies that maintain good transit service while keeping costs moderate for both transit users and drivers. 2. Lower transit fares ($0.75-$1.25) preferred given significant transit usage. 3. Moderate driving fees ($0.50) acceptable to reduce congestion while not overly burdening drivers. 4. Moderate tax rates (1%) to support transit without excessive burden. 5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel times to 51-55 minutes while maintaining reasonable driving times.

disposable_income: North Center is an affluent area with median household income around $110,000, significantly above Chicago's average. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Area has high discretionary spending power, with many residents spending on dining, entertainment, and retail. Higher sales tax would have moderate impact but not severely constrain spending habits
accessibility: Well-served by Brown Line, multiple bus routes, and major arterial roads. 71% of residents commute by car, 21% by transit. Area has good transportation options and infrastructure for both modes
decision_rationale: 1. Given high income levels, prioritize time savings over cost sensitivity. 2. Support policies that improve both transit and driving times since area uses both modes significantly. 3. Can absorb higher taxes/fees for better service. 4. Higher driver fees acceptable to reduce congestion. 5. Moderate transit fares to maintain ridership. Selected policies balance these factors while delivering good time savings for both modes

disposable_income: Lake View is an affluent area with median household income around $90,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs. Many residents work in professional services and have stable incomes.
discretionary_consumption: The area has high discretionary spending power, with numerous restaurants, entertainment venues, and retail shops. Residents frequently engage in recreational activities and dining out. Higher sales taxes would have a moderate but not severe impact on consumption patterns.
accessibility: Lake View has excellent transit access with multiple L lines (Red, Brown, Purple) and numerous bus routes. High walkability score and bike-friendly infrastructure. Many residents commute to downtown. Car ownership is lower than city average, with many households being car-free by choice.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that improve transit service given high transit usage in area. 2. Higher income means community can tolerate some fare/tax increases if they lead to better service. 3. Support driving fees to reduce congestion and fund transit since many residents don't drive. 4. Balance between service improvements and cost increases since many young professionals are price-sensitive. 5. Favor policies that reduce transit travel times most significantly since many residents rely on transit for commuting.

disposable_income: Lincoln Park is one of Chicago's most affluent neighborhoods with median household income over $115,000. Residents have high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending on retail, dining, and entertainment. The community has significant retail corridors and residents tend to make frequent trips for shopping and leisure activities
accessibility: Well-served by public transit with multiple L stations (Red/Brown/Purple lines) and bus routes. High car ownership rates but also high walkability and bikeability. Many residents commute downtown for work
decision_rationale: 1. Given high incomes, can tolerate higher fees/taxes to fund better service. 2. Many residents use both transit and cars, so balanced approach needed. 3. Reducing congestion important given density and retail corridors. 4. Higher driver fees acceptable to encourage transit use. 5. Prefer moderate-to-high tax rates to fund transit improvements. 6. Selected policies that reduce transit times while keeping reasonable fares. 7. Ranked proposals prioritizing overall system efficiency over lowest costs

disposable_income: Near North Side has one of the highest median household incomes in Chicago (over $100,000). Residents have significant disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending, with numerous luxury retail, dining, and entertainment venues. Residents typically spend more on goods/services, so sales tax impact is notable but manageable
accessibility: Excellent transit access with multiple L lines, bus routes, and walkable streets. High car ownership but also heavy traffic congestion. Many residents use mix of transit and driving depending on destination
decision_rationale: 1. Given high income levels, prioritize time savings over cost sensitivity. 2. Support better transit service through moderate fees/taxes since many residents use both modes. 3. Favor balanced proposals that improve both transit and driving times. 4. Consider higher driver fees to reduce congestion in dense area. 5. Moderate sales tax acceptable given spending patterns. Selected proposals that optimize travel times while maintaining reasonable fees

disposable_income: Edison Park is an affluent community with median household income around $87,000, significantly higher than Chicago's average. Most residents are middle to upper-middle class with good disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Residents have substantial discretionary spending power, with higher than average retail spending. The community can generally absorb moderate increases in transportation costs without severe impact on quality of life
accessibility: Located at city's far northwest edge, heavily car-dependent with 89% of households owning vehicles. Has Metra station but limited CTA bus service. Most residents drive to work with average commute times of 35-40 minutes. Good road access to expressways
decision_rationale:
1. Given high car dependency and income levels, policies with moderate driving fees are acceptable if they reduce congestion
2. Higher sales tax is less impactful due to good income levels, if it improves transit
3. Transit fare less critical since fewer residents rely on transit
4. Prioritize policies that significantly reduce driving times
5. Balance between driving costs and time savings important for car-dependent population

disposable_income: Norwood Park is an upper-middle-class area with median household income around $82,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income and car ownership rates. Many households can afford higher transportation costs without severe budget constraints.
discretionary_consumption: The area has significant discretionary spending capacity. Residents generally prioritize convenience and time savings over minor cost increases. The 1-1.5% sales tax impact on $82,000 income ($820-1230 annually) is manageable for most households.
accessibility: The area is car-dependent with good road access but limited transit options. The Blue Line terminus is at the edge of the community, and bus service is moderate. Most residents rely on cars for daily trips. Travel time differences between car and transit are significant (20-25 min vs 50-60 min).
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency, policies with moderate driving fees ($0.50) are preferred as they reduce congestion while remaining affordable. 2. Higher sales tax (1-1.5%) is acceptable given income levels and will improve transit. 3. Moderate transit fares ($1.25) balance revenue generation with maintaining transit affordability. 4. Prioritized policies that significantly reduce car travel times (to 18-19 min) while keeping costs reasonable. 5. Selected options that improve transit times to 50-52 min for those who depend on it.

disposable_income: Jefferson Park is a middle-class community with median household income around $71,000. Many residents are working professionals and city workers. The area has relatively high homeownership rates and stable housing costs.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending power but are price-sensitive to additional taxes and fees. Many households have significant expenses related to housing, transportation, and family needs.
accessibility: The area is well-served by public transit with the Jefferson Park Transit Center (Blue Line, Metra, buses). However, many residents still rely on cars for work commutes and daily errands. The community has good road access via I-90 and major arterials.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize balanced options that don't overly burden middle-class residents with high taxes/fees
2. Consider strong transit presence but acknowledge car dependency for many trips
3. Look for proposals that improve both transit and driving times without excessive costs
4. Favor moderate fare increases over high sales tax due to impact on overall household budgets
5. Value proposals that reduce congestion while maintaining affordability

disposable_income: Forest Glen is an affluent area with median household income around $106,000, significantly higher than Chicago's average. Residents have relatively high disposable income and can generally afford higher transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have substantial discretionary spending power. The community has high rates of car ownership and home ownership, indicating capacity to absorb moderate increases in transportation costs without severe impact on other consumption
accessibility: Forest Glen is a car-dependent suburban-style neighborhood with limited transit access. Most residents rely on cars for commuting. The area has Metra access but limited CTA bus service. The Blue Line is not within walking distance for most residents
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency and income levels, policies that improve driving times without excessive fees are preferred. 2. Higher sales tax is acceptable given income levels if it improves overall transportation. 3. Moderate transit fares are acceptable since transit usage is lower. 4. Focus on reducing congestion through balanced driver fees. 5. Selected policies that provide best driving times while keeping fees reasonable for frequent car users. Ranked proposals that balance improved car travel times with moderate cost increases, as most residents drive frequently

disposable_income: North Park has a median household income of around $65,000, placing it in the middle-upper range for Chicago. Many residents are working professionals and families with moderate disposable income.

accessibility: North Park has decent transit access with CTA bus routes and proximity to the Brown Line, though not as extensive as downtown areas. Many residents rely on both driving and transit. The area has good road connectivity but experiences moderate congestion during peak hours.

Moderate tax rates (1%) are acceptable to maintain service quality without excessive burden. 3. Lower transit fares preferred to encourage transit use while maintaining accessibility. 4. Moderate driving fees ($0.50) can help fund transit without being punitive. 5. Consider travel time improvements for both modes since residents use both. Selected proposals balance these factors while maintaining reasonable costs and improved service levels.

2. Moderate tax rates preferred to balance transit improvement and household budget impact
3. Lower transit fares less critical due to limited transit usage

disposable_income: Near South Side has relatively high median household income around $83,000. Many residents are professionals and higher-income workers with significant disposable income. The area has seen substantial development of luxury condos and apartments.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have high discretionary spending capacity and frequently use both transit and cars. The area has many retail establishments, restaurants, and entertainment venues. Higher sales taxes would impact discretionary spending but most households can absorb the cost.
accessibility: The area has excellent transit access with multiple L lines (Red, Green, Orange), bus routes, and Metra stations. It's also very walkable and bikeable. Many residents commute to the Loop. While car ownership is high, many households are not car-dependent due to good transit options.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize proposals that balance transit improvements with moderate costs given the area's affluence and multi-modal nature. 2. Higher driver fees acceptable as many residents have options and can afford them. 3. Moderate sales tax increase reasonable given income levels. 4. Lower transit fares less critical due to income levels. 5. Focus on reducing travel times for both modes since residents use both. Selected proposals that reduce transit times significantly while keeping costs manageable for both modes.

disposable_income: Armour Square has a median household income of approximately $35,000, significantly below Chicago's average. The community has a high percentage of low-income residents and seniors, making them particularly sensitive to cost increases
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Many residents spend a large portion of their income on basic necessities. The community has a high concentration of Asian Americans, particularly Chinese Americans, who frequently travel to local businesses in Chinatown
accessibility: Well-served by public transit including Red Line L station and multiple bus routes. High transit dependency with lower car ownership rates. Close proximity to downtown and major employment centers. Many residents rely on transit for daily commuting and accessing essential services
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize low transit fares due to high transit dependency and lower incomes
2. Prefer lower sales tax rates as residents have limited discretionary income
3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening local businesses
4. Balance between transit service improvements and cost burden on residents
5. Consider impacts on local business accessibility for both transit users and drivers

disposable_income: Douglas has a median household income of approximately $35,000, significantly below Chicago's average. About 30% of residents live below poverty level, indicating limited disposable income for many households
discretionary_consumption: Given the low median income, residents have limited discretionary spending capacity. Many households spend a large portion of income on essential needs, making them sensitive to additional taxes and transportation costs
accessibility: Douglas has good transit access with Green Line stations and multiple bus routes. About 45% of households don't own cars. Many residents rely on public transit for work commutes and daily activities. The area has relatively high transit dependency
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares due to high transit dependency and low income levels. 2. Prefer lower sales tax rates as residents have limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening car-owning households. 4. Balance between transit service improvements and cost burden on residents. 5. Consider proposals that reduce transit travel times to improve accessibility for transit-dependent population

disposable_income: Oakland is a low-income community with median household income around $27,000, significantly below Chicago's average. About 39% of residents live below poverty level, indicating limited disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Given the high poverty rate and low income levels, residents have very limited discretionary spending capacity. Most income goes to essential needs like housing and food. Higher taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets
accessibility: Oakland has good access to CTA services with Green Line and bus routes. About 45% of residents rely on public transit for commuting. Car ownership is lower than city average due to economic constraints. The community is well-served by transit but travel times are still considerable
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lowest transit fares ($0.75) to maintain affordability for transit-dependent residents. 2. Prefer lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 4. Balance between improved transit times and cost burden. 5. Consider proposals that reduce both transit and driving times while keeping costs manageable for low-income residents

disposable_income: Fuller Park has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $21,000. The community faces significant economic challenges with a poverty rate over 40% and high unemployment. Residents are particularly sensitive to any increases in transportation costs or taxes.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, residents have very limited discretionary spending capacity. Most income goes to essential needs like housing and food. Even small increases in transportation costs or sales tax would significantly impact household budgets.
accessibility: The community has access to CTA Red Line and Green Line stations and several bus routes. Car ownership is low due to economic constraints. Many residents rely heavily on public transit for accessing jobs and services. The area experiences some isolation due to being bounded by rail yards and expressways.
decision_rationale: 1. Given very low incomes, prioritize lowest combined costs (fare + tax + fees). 2. Strong transit dependency means better transit service times are important. 3. Lower sales tax preferred due to limited discretionary spending. 4. Lower transit fares more important than driving fees since most residents use transit. 5. Selected proposals 0, 9, 3, 18, 21 because they combine: lowest sales tax (0.5-1.5%), low transit fares ($0.75-1.25), no driving fees, and reasonable transit times.

disposable_income: Grand Boulevard has a lower median household income around $30,000, with about 39% of residents living below poverty level. This indicates limited disposable income and high sensitivity to cost increases.
discretionary_consumption: Given the income levels, discretionary spending is limited. Many residents rely on essential purchases and are price-sensitive to both sales tax increases and transportation costs.
accessibility: The area has good transit access with Green and Red Line stations and multiple bus routes. About 42% of households don't own vehicles and rely heavily on public transit. Those who do drive face significant commute times.
decision_rationale: 1. Given low incomes, prioritize lowest combined costs (fare + tax) while maintaining service quality. 2. Strong transit dependency means transit travel times are critical. 3. Lower fares ($0.75) benefit the large transit-dependent population. 4. Moderate driving fees can help fund transit without overly burdening local drivers. 5. Higher sales tax is less preferred due to impact on essential purchases. Selected proposals balance these factors, with preference for low fares and moderate fees to support transit service while keeping overall costs manageable for residents.

disposable_income: Kenwood has a mixed-income population with a median household income around $45,000, though there are also affluent areas. About 20% of residents live below poverty line, so transportation costs are significant for many residents
discretionary_consumption: Significant variation in discretionary spending power across neighborhood. Many residents are price-sensitive to both transit fares and sales tax increases. Higher-income residents have more flexibility to absorb increased costs
accessibility: Well-served by CTA buses and Green Line, with good access to downtown. About 35% of residents rely on public transit for commuting. Relatively high car ownership but also significant transit dependency. Close to Lake Shore Drive and major arterials
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that maintain affordable transit access while improving service quality given mixed income levels and significant transit reliance. 2. Moderate tax increases acceptable if they yield better transit service. 3. Support some driving fees to fund transit and reduce congestion, but avoid highest fees. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts on lower-income residents. 5. Selected policies that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable and implementing moderate driving fees to encourage transit use

disposable_income: Washington Park is one of Chicago's lowest-income communities with median household income around $25,000. Many residents live below poverty line and have very limited disposable income. High unemployment rate (~40%) further constrains household budgets.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, residents have minimal discretionary spending capacity. Most income goes to basic necessities. Even small increases in transportation costs or taxes would significantly impact household budgets.
accessibility: The area has good access to CTA Green Line and bus routes. Car ownership is low (~40% of households). Many residents rely heavily on public transit for work, shopping, and services. Travel times by transit are important for accessing jobs and opportunities.
decision_rationale:
1. Given low incomes, prioritize lowest combined costs (fares, fees, taxes)
2. Strong transit dependency means better transit service times are crucial
3. Lower transit fares are more important than driving fees since most residents use transit
4. Moderate tax rates can help fund transit while not overly burdening limited budgets
5. Selected policies balance improved transit service with affordability

disposable_income: Hyde Park has a mixed-income population with a median household income around $53,000. Large student population from University of Chicago affects the overall income profile. About 25% of residents live below poverty line while also having significant professional population.
discretionary_consumption: Significant portion of residents are students and academics with moderate discretionary spending. Retail and entertainment spending concentrated around 53rd Street and University campus. Many residents balance education expenses with other needs.
accessibility: Well-served by public transit with Metra Electric, CTA buses, and proximity to Green Line. High walkability score. Many residents are car-free by choice. University provides additional shuttle services. Good bicycle infrastructure.

1. Prioritize lower transit fares due to large student/academic population reliant on public transit
2. Moderate tax rate acceptable given mixed-income profile and strong public benefits orientation
3. Support higher driving fees as community has good transit alternatives
4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times given high transit usage
5. Balance need for transit system funding with affordability for lower-income residents

Moderate tax rates preferred due to middle-class household budgets. 3. Lower transit fares beneficial for airport workers and transit-dependent residents. 4. Some driving fees acceptable to improve transit service but not highest rates. 5. Focus on policies that reduce transit travel times to increase competitiveness with driving.

disposable_income: West Lawn is a middle-class community with median household income around $54,000. Many residents work in service and industrial sectors. The community has moderate disposable income but is price-sensitive to transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have modest discretionary spending capacity. Higher sales taxes would impact household budgets. Many families need to balance transportation costs with other essential expenses
accessibility: The community has moderate transit access with bus routes but no L train stations. Car ownership is high at around 85% of households. Many residents rely on driving for work commutes and daily activities. Travel times to downtown and other job centers are significant
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower sales tax (0.5%) to preserve discretionary income for middle-class families. 2. Moderate driving fees ($0.50) can help improve transit without excessive burden on car-dependent residents. 3. Lower transit fares ($0.75-$1.25) benefit transit users while maintaining service quality. 4. Balance between car and transit travel times important as community uses both modes. 5. Selected proposals reduce transit travel times by 10-15% while keeping driving costs manageable

disposable_income: Chicago Lawn is a lower-middle income community with median household income around $37,000. Many residents face economic constraints, making them sensitive to transportation costs and taxes
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Residents typically spend significant portion of income on essential needs, making them vulnerable to increased taxes and fees
accessibility: Good transit access with multiple bus routes and proximity to Orange Line. Car ownership rate is moderate but many households rely on public transit. Mixed-use neighborhood with local businesses and services requiring regular transportation
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize lower transit fares due to high transit dependency and limited income
2. Prefer moderate tax rates to balance service quality and household budget impact
3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service while not overly burdening drivers
4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel time to improve accessibility
5. Consider combined impact of taxes, fares, and fees on household budgets

disposable_income: West Englewood has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $27,000. Many residents live below the poverty line, making disposable income extremely limited. The community has a high unemployment rate and many households rely on public assistance.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, discretionary spending is very limited. Most household income goes to basic necessities like housing, food, and utilities. Additional taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact already strained household budgets.
accessibility: The community has high transit dependency with lower car ownership rates. Many residents rely on public transit to access jobs, services and resources. The area is served by CTA buses and the Red Line, but transit travel times are long compared to driving. Improving transit affordability and service quality is crucial.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lowest transit fares ($0.75) to maintain affordability for transit-dependent residents. 2. Favor lower sales tax rates (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without excessive burden. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping costs low for this low-income, transit-reliant community.

disposable_income: Englewood has one of the lowest median household incomes in Chicago at around $20,000 annually. Many residents live below poverty level and have very limited disposable income. Cost sensitivity is extremely high.
discretionary_consumption: Given the low income levels, discretionary spending is minimal. Most household income goes to basic necessities. Even small increases in transportation costs or sales tax would significantly impact residents' ability to meet basic needs.
accessibility: High transit dependency with lower car ownership rates compared to city average. Many residents rely on public transit for access to jobs, healthcare, and essential services. Current transit service is limited with longer travel times. Walking and bus are primary modes.
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize lowest combined costs (fare + tax) given very low incomes
2. Focus on improved transit service/times since many depend on transit
3. Avoid high driving fees since they would burden essential workers who must drive
4. Balance between service improvements and affordability
5. Selected proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping fares low
6. Ranked options with 0.5-1.0% tax rates higher than 1.5% due to impact on basic consumption
7. Preferred $0.75 fare options to maintain transit affordability

disposable_income: Greater Grand Crossing is a lower-income community with median household income around $31,000. Many residents live below poverty level. Disposable income is limited, making residents particularly sensitive to transportation costs.
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to low income levels. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets. Many residents need to prioritize essential expenses over discretionary purchases.
accessibility: The community has good transit access with multiple bus routes and Red/Green Line stations. Car ownership is lower than city average. Many residents rely on public transit for work commutes and daily needs. Current transit travel times are challenging for residents.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares due to limited household incomes and high transit dependency. 2. Favor lower sales tax rates to protect limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening car-dependent trips. 4. Balance travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Selected policies that reduce transit travel times while keeping fares affordable. Ranked proposals offering best combination of low fares, improved transit times, and manageable tax burden.

disposable_income: Ashburn has a median household income of around $65,000, which is slightly above Chicago's median. However, with significant homeownership costs and family expenses, residents are cost-sensitive to transportation expenses
discretionary_consumption: Moderate discretionary spending capacity, with many working-class and middle-class families. Higher sales taxes would impact household budgets, especially for larger families common in this area
accessibility: Heavily car-dependent community with limited public transit options. Most residents rely on personal vehicles, though some use Metra Rock Island line at the edge of the neighborhood. Long commute times to downtown and other employment centers
decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize policies that don't overly burden drivers given high car dependency
2. Prefer lower sales tax rates due to impact on family budgets
3. Balance driving fees to improve transit without excessive cost to drivers
4. Consider moderate fare increases acceptable if they improve service
5. Focus on proposals that reduce overall travel time while keeping costs manageable

disposable_income: Auburn Gresham is a predominantly lower-income community with median household income around $35,000, significantly below Chicago's average. Many residents face economic challenges with limited disposable income
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Residents are price-sensitive to additional taxes and fees. Many households spend a significant portion of income on basic necessities
accessibility: High transit dependency with about 30% of households lacking vehicle access. The community is served by CTA Red Line (95th), bus routes, and Metra Rock Island line. Many residents rely on public transit for work commutes and daily activities
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize low transit fares ($0.75) due to high transit dependency and limited income. 2. Prefer lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on already constrained budgets. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50-$1.00) to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 4. Balance between improved transit times and affordability. 5. Consider proposals that reduce both transit and driving times to benefit all residents

disposable_income: Beverly is an upper-middle-class community with median household income around $94,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income compared to Chicago average, making them less sensitive to moderate fare/fee increases
discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending capacity. Many households can afford cars and have flexibility in transportation choices. Higher sales tax would have noticeable but manageable impact on discretionary spending
accessibility: Well-served by Metra Rock Island line with three stations. Good road network but some traffic congestion. Many residents commute downtown. Car ownership is high at around 90% of households. Mixed transit-car usage patterns
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that balance driving and transit improvements since Beverly uses both modes heavily. 2. Can tolerate moderate fees/taxes given income levels. 3. Focus on reducing transit travel times since many use Metra for downtown commutes. 4. Higher driver fees acceptable to fund transit and reduce congestion. 5. Moderate sales tax preferred to maintain discretionary spending. Selected policies that provide best travel time improvements while keeping costs reasonable for both modes

disposable_income: Washington Heights has a median household income of approximately $41,000, which is below Chicago's median. Many residents face economic constraints, making them sensitive to transportation costs and taxes
discretionary_consumption: Limited discretionary spending capacity due to lower income levels. Residents need to carefully balance essential expenses with transportation costs. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact household budgets
accessibility: The community has access to Metra Rail (95th Street station) and several bus routes, but many residents rely on personal vehicles. Transit travel times are significantly longer than driving. The area is relatively car-dependent for access to jobs and services
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares and sales tax due to limited disposable income. 2. Consider moderate driving fees to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 3. Balance between transit improvement and cost burden. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel time while keeping fares affordable. 5. Selected proposals that maintain reasonable driving costs while improving transit service. Proposals 0, 1, 9, 10, and 3 provide the best balance of affordability and service improvement for the community's socioeconomic profile

disposable_income: Mount Greenwood is a middle to upper-middle class area with median household income around $87,000. Many residents are city workers, particularly police and firefighters, with stable incomes. The area has one of the highest rates of homeownership in Chicago.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate to high discretionary spending power. The community has high car ownership rates and most households can absorb moderate increases in transportation costs without severe impact on other spending.
accessibility: The area is car-dependent with limited public transit options. Located on the far southwest side, it's relatively far from downtown. Most residents rely on personal vehicles. The area has Metra service but infrequent bus service. The 111th Street commercial corridor is the main shopping area.
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency, avoid highest driving fees to prevent excessive burden on residents. 2. Moderate tax increase acceptable to improve transit while maintaining driving viability. 3. Higher transit fares acceptable since most residents drive. 4. Prioritize policies that reduce car travel times since most commute by car. 5. Balance between maintaining reasonable driving costs while funding some transit improvements through moderate taxes and fees.

disposable_income: Morgan Park has a median household income of approximately $57,000, which is moderate for Chicago. About 15% of residents live below poverty level, indicating a significant portion of the population needs to be mindful of transportation costs
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending power, but many households need to carefully budget transportation expenses. The community has a mix of middle-class and working-class families who are sensitive to both tax increases and fare/fee changes
accessibility: Morgan Park is served by Metra Rock Island Line and several bus routes, but transit service is less frequent than in areas closer to downtown. About 75% of households own cars, indicating high car dependency. The community is relatively far from downtown, making both driving and transit times significant factors
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize policies that balance transit improvement with moderate costs given mixed-income population. 2. Consider high car ownership but need for viable transit options. 3. Lower sales tax preferred due to moderate income levels. 4. Moderate driving fees acceptable to improve transit without excessive burden. 5. Prefer policies that reduce transit travel time given distance from downtown. Selected policies that offer improved transit times without highest tax burden, while maintaining reasonable driving costs for car-dependent residents

disposable_income: O'Hare has a median household income above city average at around $67,000. Many residents work in airport-related industries or nearby business districts. The community has relatively high disposable income compared to many Chicago neighborhoods
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate to high discretionary spending capacity. The area has many retail establishments and restaurants. Higher sales taxes would impact discretionary spending but most households can absorb moderate increases
accessibility: The area is highly car-dependent due to its location and layout. While served by the CTA Blue Line, many parts of O'Hare require driving. The community has high car ownership rates and many residents rely on driving for work commutes, especially airport workers with irregular hours
decision_rationale: 1. Given high car dependency, avoid highest driving fees to prevent excessive burden on residents who must drive. 2. Moderate tax increase acceptable to improve transit while maintaining discretionary spending power. 3. Higher transit fares acceptable since most residents drive. 4. Prioritize policies that reduce driving times given heavy traffic in area. 5. Balance between generating revenue for transit improvements while keeping costs reasonable for driving-dependent residents

disposable_income: Edgewater has a median household income of around $54,000, slightly below Chicago's median. About 16% of residents live below poverty level. The community has a mix of middle-income and lower-income households, making cost sensitivity important.
discretionary_consumption: Residents have moderate discretionary spending capacity. Higher sales taxes would impact local businesses and residents' purchasing power. Many residents need to balance transportation costs with other essential expenses.
accessibility: Well-served by CTA Red Line and multiple bus routes. About 35% of residents use public transit for commuting, 35% drive, and others walk or bike. High transit accessibility with multiple options available. Dense, walkable neighborhood with good access to local amenities.
decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares due to high transit usage and moderate income levels. 2. Moderate sales tax (1%) balances revenue needs with economic impact. 3. Support driving fees to improve transit service and reduce congestion. 4. Focus on proposals that reduce transit travel times to benefit large transit-dependent population. 5. Consider balance between car and transit improvements given mixed mode share.
